title: IS415 - Group 5
text:
Welcome to IS415 Geospatial Analytics and Applications - Team 5
This is our team’s Geospatial Analytics and Applications Group Project Website!

The Team
Daniel Chng - Daniel.Chng.2020@scis.smu.edu.sg
Leon Tan - Leon.Tan.2020@scis.smu.edu.sg
Zoe Chia - Alanischia.2018x@scis.smu.edu.sg

title: EDA
text:
# Import Packages
pacman::p_load(sf, tmap, tidyverse, sfdep, readxl, Kendall, plotly, plyr, SpatialAcc, ggstatsplot, reshape2, fca, sp, caret, stplanr, broom, geojsonio, jsonlite, dplyr)

title: EDA
text:
MPSZ

# Import MPSZ
mpsz <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MPSZ-2019")

Reading layer `MPSZ-2019' from data source 
  `C:\Users\Daniel\Desktop\Github\IS419\IS415-Project\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 332 features and 6 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84



mpsz <- st_transform(mpsz, 3414)


is.null(mpsz)

[1] FALSE



mpsz <- st_make_valid(mpsz)


write_rds(mpsz, "data/model/mpsz.rds")

title: EDA
text:
MRT

# Import MRT Stations
mrt <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "RapidTransitSystemStation")

Reading layer `RapidTransitSystemStation' from data source 
  `C:\Users\Daniel\Desktop\Github\IS419\IS415-Project\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 220 features and 4 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 6068.209 ymin: 27478.44 xmax: 45377.5 ymax: 47913.58
Projected CRS: SVY21

mrt_sf <- st_transform(mrt, 3414)


mrt_sf <- mrt_sf %>%
  filter(str_detect(mrt_sf$STN_NAM_DE, "MRT STATION|LRT STATION")) %>%
  dplyr::select(c(4, 3, 5))


mrt_sf[rowSums(is.na(mrt_sf))!=0,]

Simple feature collection with 0 features and 2 fields
Bounding box:  xmin: NA ymin: NA xmax: NA ymax: NA
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
[1] STN_NAM_DE TYP_CD_DES geometry  
<0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)



st_is_valid(mrt_sf)

title: EDA
text:
MRT Rail Line

# MRT Rail Line
rail <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "G_MP14_RAIL_LI")

Reading layer `G_MP14_RAIL_LI' from data source 
  `C:\Users\Daniel\Desktop\Github\IS419\IS415-Project\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 1399 features and 9 fields (with 2 geometries empty)
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 5950.856 ymin: 26030.91 xmax: 45473.16 ymax: 48252.23
Projected CRS: SVY21

rail_sf <- st_transform(rail, 3414)


rail_sf <- rail_sf %>%
  filter(TYPE %in%
           c("MRT",
             "LRT",
             "CCL")) %>%
  dplyr::select(c(1))


rail_sf[rowSums(is.na(rail_sf))!=0,]

Simple feature collection with 0 features and 1 field
Bounding box:  xmin: NA ymin: NA xmax: NA ymax: NA
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM

title: EDA
text:
Tourism

# Tourism
tourism_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "TOURISM")

Reading layer `TOURISM' from data source 
  `C:\Users\Daniel\Desktop\Github\IS419\IS415-Project\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 107 features and 19 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: -1.797693e+308 ymin: -1.797693e+308 xmax: 43659.54 ymax: 47596.73
Projected CRS: SVY21

# Assign EPSG Code
tourism_sf <- st_transform(tourism_sf, 3414) %>%
  dplyr::select(c(6, 10, 20))


tourism_sf[rowSums(is.na(tourism_sf))!=0,]

Simple feature collection with 2 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: -1.797693e+308 ymin: -1.797693e+308 xmax: 28447.06 ymax: 28853.86
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
                PAGETITLE ADDRESS                       geometry
4              Shophouses    <NA>      POINT (28447.06 28853.86)
73 Cruises from Singapore    <NA> POINT (-1.797693e+308 -1.79...



tourism_sf <- na.omit(tourism_sf,c("Shophouses", "Cruises from Singapore"))


is(tourism_sf, "sf")

[1] TRUE



write_rds(tourism_sf, "data/model/tourism_sf.rds")

title: EDA
text:
Shopping Malls

# Shopping Malls
shopping <- read.csv("data/geospatial/mall_coordinates.csv")

shopping <- shopping %>%
  dplyr::select(name, latitude, longitude)


shopping_sf <- st_as_sf(shopping,
                              coords = c("longitude",
                                         "latitude"),
                              crs = 4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)


write_rds(shopping_sf, "data/model/shopping_sf.rds")

title: EDA
text:
Population

# Population Data 2022
popdata <- read_csv("data/aspatial/respopagesexfa2022.csv")


popdata2022 <- popdata %>%
  spread(AG, Pop) %>%
  mutate(YOUNG = `0_to_4`+`5_to_9`+`10_to_14`+
`15_to_19`+`20_to_24`) %>%
mutate(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` = rowSums(.[9:13])+
rowSums(.[15:17]))%>%
mutate(`AGED`=rowSums(.[18:22])) %>%
mutate(`TOTAL`=rowSums(.[5:22])) %>%  
mutate(`DEPENDENCY` = (`YOUNG` + `AGED`)
/`ECONOMY ACTIVE`) %>%
mutate_at(.vars = vars(PA, SZ), toupper) %>%
dplyr::select(`PA`, `SZ`, `YOUNG`, `ECONOMY ACTIVE`, `AGED`, 
       `TOTAL`, `DEPENDENCY`) %>%
  filter(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` > 0)


popdata2022 <- popdata2022 %>%
  mutate_at(.vars = vars(PA, SZ), 
          .funs = funs(toupper)) %>%
  filter(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` > 0)


write_rds(popdata2022, "data/model/popdata2022.rds")


mpsz_popdata2022 <- left_join(mpsz, popdata2022, by = c("SUBZONE_N" = "SZ"))


write_rds(mpsz_popdata2022, "data/model/mpsz_popdata2022.rds")


summary(mpsz_popdata2022$DEPENDENCY)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
 0.0000  0.6786  0.8645  0.9583  1.0000 17.0000      99

title: EDA
text:
MRT & MPSZ

mrt_mpsz <- st_join(mrt_sf, mpsz)


mrt_mpsz <- mrt_mpsz %>%
  select(c(1,7))


mrt_mpsz <- na.omit(mrt_mpsz)


# MRT vs MPSZ
tmap_mode('view')
tmap_options(check.and.fix = TRUE) +
tm_shape(mpsz) +
  tm_polygons() +
tm_shape(mrt_mpsz) +
  tm_dots(alph=0.5, size=0.07) +
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,14))







write_rds(mrt_mpsz, "data/model/mrt_mpsz.rds")

title: EDA
text:
Import Shapefiles

# Hexagon for Map
hexagon <- readRDS("data/model/hexagon_sf.rds")


# Tourism
tourism <- readRDS("data/model/tourism_sf.rds")


shopping <- readRDS("data/model/shopping_sf.rds")


# Import MRT Stations
mrt_mpsz <- readRDS("data/model/mrt_mpsz.rds")


#Import MRT Rail
mrt_rail <- readRDS("data/model/rail_sf.rds")

title: EDA
text:
Calculate Distance Matrix

hexagon <- hexagon %>%
  dplyr::select(fid) %>%
  mutate(demand = 100)


mrt_mpsz <- mrt_mpsz %>%
  mutate(demand = 100)


shopping <- shopping %>%
  mutate(capacity = 100)


tourism <- tourism %>%
  dplyr::select(PAGETITLE) %>%
  mutate(capacity = 100)


Hexagon x Tourism

tourism_coord <- st_coordinates(tourism)
hexagon_coord <- st_centroid(hexagon) %>%
  st_coordinates()


hex_tour <- SpatialAcc::distance(hexagon_coord,
                                  tourism_coord,
                                  type = "euclidean")

hex_tour_km <- as.matrix(hex_tour/1000)


Hansen

acc_Hansen <- data.frame(ac(hexagon$demand,
                            tourism$capacity,
                            hex_tour_km,
                            #d0 = 50,
                            power = 2,
                            family = "Hansen"))

colnames(acc_Hansen) <- "accHansen"
acc_Hansen <- as_tibble(acc_Hansen)
hex_tour_Hansen <- bind_cols(hexagon, acc_Hansen)


write_rds(hex_tour_Hansen, "data/model/hex_tour_Hansen.rds")


tmap_mode("view")
tm_shape(hex_tour_Hansen,
         bbox = st_bbox(hex_tour_Hansen)) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accHansen",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(mrt_mpsz) +
  tm_dots(alph=0.5, size=0.07)+
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,14)) +
tm_shape(tourism) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to Tourism: Hansen Method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)








KD2SFCA

acc_KD2SFCA <- data.frame(ac(hexagon$demand,
                            tourism$capacity,
                            hex_tour_km,
                            d0 = 50,
                            power = 2,
                            family = "KD2SFCA"))

colnames(acc_KD2SFCA) <- "accKD2SFCA"
acc_KD2SFCA <- as_tibble(acc_KD2SFCA)
hex_tour_KD2SFCA <- bind_cols(hexagon, acc_KD2SFCA)


write_rds(hex_tour_KD2SFCA, "data/model/hex_tour_KD2SFCA.rds")


tmap_mode("view")
tm_shape(hex_tour_KD2SFCA,
         bbox = st_bbox(hex_tour_KD2SFCA)) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accKD2SFCA",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(mrt_mpsz) +
  tm_dots(alph=0.5, size=0.07)+
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,14)) +
tm_shape(tourism) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to Tourism: Hansen Method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)








SAM

acc_SAM <- data.frame(ac(hexagon$demand,
                            tourism$capacity,
                            hex_tour_km,
                            d0 = 50,
                            power = 2,
                            family = "SAM"))

colnames(acc_SAM) <- "accSAM"
acc_SAM <- as_tibble(acc_SAM)
hex_tour_SAM <- bind_cols(hexagon, acc_SAM)


write_rds(hex_tour_SAM, "data/model/hex_tour_SAM.rds")


tmap_mode("view")
tm_shape(hex_tour_SAM,
         bbox = st_bbox(hex_tour_SAM)) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accSAM",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(mrt_mpsz) +
  tm_dots(alph=0.5, size=0.07)+
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,14)) +
tm_shape(tourism) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to Tourism: Hansen Method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)









MRT x Tourism

tourism_coord <- st_coordinates(tourism)
mrt_coord <- st_centroid(mrt_mpsz) %>%
  st_coordinates()


mrt_tour <- SpatialAcc::distance(mrt_coord,
                                  tourism_coord,
                                  type = "euclidean")

mrt_tour_km <- as.matrix(mrt_tour/1000)


Hansen

acc_Hansen <- data.frame(ac(mrt_mpsz$demand,
                            tourism$capacity,
                            mrt_tour_km,
                            #d0 = 50,
                            power = 2,
                            family = "Hansen"))

colnames(acc_Hansen) <- "accHansen"
acc_Hansen <- as_tibble(acc_Hansen)
mrt_tour_Hansen <- bind_cols(mrt_mpsz, acc_Hansen)


write_rds(mrt_tour_Hansen, "data/model/mrt_tour_Hansen.rds")


# MRT & Tourism
tmap_mode('view')
tm_shape(tourism) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.5) +
tm_shape(mrt_mpsz) +
  tm_dots(alph=0.1, size=0.1)+
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,14)) +
tm_shape(mrt_tour_Hansen) +
  tm_bubbles(col = "accHansen",
             n = 5,
             style = "quantile",
             size = 0.2,
             border.col = "black",
             border.lwd = 1)








Boxplot

mrt_tour_boxplot <- mrt_tour_Hansen


write_rds(mrt_tour_boxplot, "data/model/mrt_tour_boxplot.rds")


ggplot(data=mrt_tour_boxplot, 
       aes(y = log(accHansen), 
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(fun.y = "mean", 
                   geom = "point", 
                   colour = "red", 
                   size = 2)

title: Project Proposal
text:
With the rapid expansion of Singapore’s Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) and Light Rail Transit (LRT) systems as seen in the Rail Expansion Plan above, we need to understand the effectiveness of these stations in serving the people in terms of accessibility. Should these new stations not be useful for Singaporeans in bringing them to places, it will only bring a negative ROI in terms of financial and possible environmental impacts.
Geographical accessibility and spatial interaction models are important considerations for any transportation network, and this is especially true for the in Singapore. These systems provide an essential transportation link for commuters across the city-state, and its accessibility can have a significant impact on the overall mobility and quality of life of residents.




Find out how accessible MRT and LRT stations are for Singapore commuters.
Find out which MRT/LRT station is the most accessible/inaccessible.
Find out how well is the coverage of MRT & LRT services in Singapore.
Visualise how the locations of MRT & LRT are related with its surroundings. (e.g. School, Shopping Malls, etc.)





Mapping MRT & LRT Stations: A first step in any geospatial project on MRT & LRT accessibility would be to map the location of all MRT & LRT stations across the city. This can be done using a variety of tools, including GIS software and open-source mapping platforms like OpenStreetMap.
Population Density: Once the location of MRT & LRT stations has been mapped, the next step would be to map out the Population Density of Singapore residents.
Measuring Accessibility: The next step would be to measure accessibility. This can be done using the 3 different methods: Hansen, KD2SFCA & SAM

Data Preparation

Collection of data
Importing of data
Data Wrangling

Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

Examine distribution of data points
Checking of outliers in data
Remove missing data
Cleaning up of data

Modelling and Visualising Accessibility Using:

Hansen Method

The Hansen method involves using GIS to analyze the spatial relationship between transportation infrastructure and population. It calculates the travel time between each point in the study area and the nearest transportation facility to create maps that show the level of accessibility to different types of transportation for each location. This method is useful in identifying areas that are underserved by transportation infrastructure and evaluating the potential impacts of new transportation investments, helping planners and policymakers make more informed decisions about transportation investments and ensuring that transportation services are distributed fairly.

KD2SFCA

The KD2SFCA method involves using GIS to analyze the spatial relationship between train stations and population. The method calculates the number of train stations within a certain travel time of each location, taking into account both supply and demand factors. This results in a series of maps that show the level of mrt stations’ accessibility for each location in the study area. This method is useful in identifying areas with poor accessibility to stations.

Spatial Accessibility Measure (SAM)

The Spatial Accessibility Measure (SAM) involves using GIS to analyze the spatial relationship between a service facility and a population. The method calculates the level of accessibility to the service facility for each location in the study area, taking into account factors such as travel time and distance, mode of transportation, and the size of the population served. The result is a series of maps that show the level of accessibility for each location, which can be used to identify areas that are underserved by the service facility. This method is useful in informing policy and planning decisions related to service provision, and can be applied to a range of service types, including healthcare, education, and retail.







The Geography Analysis of Singapore MRT

Objectives

Discover the population density in the different planning areas of Singapore
Explore the relationship between the population density and MRT stations
Analyse the population transported by MRT based on planning area

Things to Note

Based on the results of the maps, it was separated as the information would be to clustered if all the data is placed in one map. The team will separate the maps or graphs when necessary.
Author mentioned that it was difficult to combine all the information together, it is time consuming. Hence, the team will work on it earlier.


Analysis of the impact of the MRT system on accessibility in Singapore using an integrated GIS tool

Objectives

Understand and analysis the following accessibility:

CBD from the HDB towns
Working population in the HDB towns
Industrial opportunities in DGP zones
Commercial opportunities in the DGP zones

‘Before’ and ‘After’ between the two new MRT lines that were introduced

Things to Note

As the study was done in 2003, they faced limitation of not up to date data where certain points are impossible to analyse. The team will ensure that the data used are the most updated ones.
The authors mentioned that the study is mainly descriptive in nature, and in the future, prescriptive analysis would be able to support urban transportation planning activities with accessibility as one of the major goals. As the team is only working on Population Density with MRT & LRT stations, it is important that the end result does not deviate.






Our plan is to create a RShiny application that follows these layouts.





All the other tabs like Hansen, KD2SFCA, and SAM Method will follow this layout below.





















Toh, T.W. (5 March 2020). Parliament: $60 billion to expand and renew rail network in next decade. The Straits Times. https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/parliament-60-billion-to-expand-and-renew-rail-network-in-next-decade
Tan, A. (2 September 2019). Mitigation measures can cut wildlife impact of running Cross Island MRT line under nature reserve: LTA. The Straits Times. https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/environment/running-mrt-line-through-central-catchment-nature-reserve-may-endanger
